title: 104_hr2519
content: The "Philanthropy Protection Act of 1995" includes amendments to various financial acts such as the Investment Company Act of 1940, Securities Act of 1933, and Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to protect philanthropic organizations. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to provide exemption for companies organized for religious, educational, charitable, or similar purposes, with restrictions on earnings benefiting private individuals. This includes the maintenance of funds for collective investment by charitable organizations. Assets of charitable organizations include those held in pooled income funds, contributed in exchange for charitable gift annuities, in charitable remainder trusts, charitable lead trusts, and trusts with revocable dedication to charitable organizations under specific circumstances. Assets of charitable organizations can include funds in charitable remainder trusts with revocable dedication to charitable organizations. These assets may be excluded from the definition of an investment company for a period of 3 years under certain conditions. Assets contributed before a specified date can be excluded from the definition of an investment company if commingled with certain assets in a fund maintained by a charitable organization. Trusts or funds are considered 'maintained' by a charitable organization if they serve as trustees or administrators. The term 'pooled income fund' and 'charitable organization' are defined accordingly. The curr_chunk defines terms related to charitable organizations under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including charitable lead trust, charitable remainder trust, and charitable gift annuity. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to require exempt charitable organizations to provide written information to donors about the operation of the fund. Amendment to the Securities Act of 1933 includes adding a provision for securities of funds excluded from the definition of an investment company. Amendments to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 are also made. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include exemptions for certain securities issued by pooled income funds or collective investment funds. Additionally, a new exemption for charitable organizations is added to the Act. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include exemptions for certain securities issued by pooled income funds or collective investment funds. A charitable organization, trustee, director, officer, employee, or volunteer of such organization shall not be deemed a broker or dealer solely for buying, holding, selling, or trading securities for its own account. The exemption under the Investment Company Act of 1940 applies to trusts or donative instruments, with limitations on compensation for charitable organizations and their personnel soliciting donations for excluded funds. The Investment Company Act of 1940 exempts individuals involved in fundraising for charitable organizations from receiving commissions based on donations collected for the fund. Additionally, a conforming amendment allows for the exclusion of certain securities from the definition of an investment company under the Act. SEC. 5. AMENDMENT OF THE INVESTMENT ADVISERS ACT OF 1940. Section 203(b) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include any investment adviser that is a charitable organization or is affiliated with one, providing advice only to specific entities such as charitable organizations or excluded funds. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include investment advisers affiliated with charitable organizations, providing advice to specific entities like charitable organizations or excluded funds. The Act also covers trusts and donative instruments described in section 3(c)(10)(B) of the Investment Company Act of 1940. PROTECTION OF PHILANTHROPY UNDER STATE LAW. Exempt from state registration requirements are securities issued by certain funds excluded from the definition of an investment company. Charitable organizations and their personnel are also exempt from registration as dealers, brokers, agents, or investment advisers when trading securities for their own accounts. The Act allows entities to buy, hold, sell, or trade securities for charitable organizations, certain excluded funds, or trusts without being subject to state registration requirements. States have the option to enact laws that do not preempt this Act within a 3-year period. The section defines key terms for charitable organizations and securities, and clarifies that "State" includes various regions within the United States. SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATES AND APPLICABILITY. This Act and its amendments apply to all pending and future administrative and judicial actions as a defense against claims under certain securities laws, except where specifically provided otherwise.
